node.title: Get Jacobian in UserObject
node.bodyText:
Hello,
is there a way to get the global DOFxDOF jacobian in a UserObject?
Or do I have to assemble it myself?

Hello
We do not recommend assembling it yourself.
You should be able to use the TaggingInterface to retrieve the Jacobian. I dont know which tag you would use
If that does not work directly, the create a new matrix tag and add it to all your kernels. Then you can retrive the Jacobian with this matrix tag.
Guillaume

Actually, from the documentation, I think the system tag will be helpful
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/interfaces/TaggingInterface.html
I've noticed the Tensor Mechanics Master Action has no matrix_tags parameter. Will it still contribute to the system matrix by default?

Furthermore, I can't seem to get the matrix import working.
_subproblem.getMatrixTags();
tells me there are two matrices: SYSTEM with ID=0 and TIME with ID=1. But when I do
_sys.hasMatrix(0);
it returns false. And as expected
_sys.getMatrix(0) 
is not working either. Am I missing an include or something? What am I doing wrong here?

Will it still contribute to the system matrix by default?

yes
What do you mean missing an include? If it is compiling then you are not missing an include.
When is this object executed? I wonder if you are querying for this matrix too early

Ah okay, that's good to know.
I'm executing said commands in the initialize function of an ElementUserObject at timestep_end post_aux.
@lindsayad thoughts about who to tag on the tagging system and if you, then how would the matrix not be available then?

@maxnezdyur It works but the matrix I get is not symmetric. Shouldn't the jacobian be symmetric for a linear elastic tensor mechanics problem?
@lindsayad What is the reason for that?

@Flolaffel you'll want to add a new matrix tag for now, unless @maxnezdyur 's solution works for you
If you are going through the action and it wont let you then you ll need to modify it

node.title: convergence at low saturations
node.bodyText:
Hi,
My current simulation is running into some convergence problems. The model describes a heat source in a circular body with unsaturated soil using the NCG formulation.
The problem arises when integrating the dispersivity kernel together with physically correct diffusion coefficients for the millington quirk formulation.
Looking into the results I realised that without dispersivity the liquid saturation hovers around the initial value of roughly 32 %, without showing any effects of drying.
As soon as dispersivity is activated drying occurs, at some point throwing Max non linear iterations followed by a moose exception temperature/pressure out of  boundaries, shortly thereafter. Lowering the diffusion coefficients for h20 in the gaseous phases decreases the drying effect correspondingly. Any thoughts about the underlying problem? @GiudGiud @cpgr
Please find the input file below.
Cheers!

node.title: Boundary Condition between 2 variables
node.bodyText:
Hi there,
Thank you for all the help you have offered so far.
The problem I'm solving requires me to use a complex variable. As Moose doesn't handle complex values, I have split it into real and imaginary parts, such that C = a +i*b.
a and b are variables that are solved by kernels here.
I want to set a boundary condition such that the magnitude of C =1, hence a^2+b^2=1.
How would i go about doing this?
All the best,
Gillian

Hello
You can write a dirichlet BC that involves another variable.
I would use that to set the value of one variable based on the variable of another
Either that or write a constraint instead
Guillaume

Hi Guillamume,
Thanks, for the help.
Yep, that makes sense.
Is there an example that you would recommend for me to look at to write the BC/ base it on?
All the best,
Gillian

I have implemented this, as in the example page here, (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/examples/ex04_bcs.html).
The solve now won't converge.
I want to clarify, what happens to the boundary condition on the other variable in this case. Will it also be adjusted? Will it default to a different BC?
As you now have one BC that's active on one variable, but actually it is acting on 2 variables.
Thank you

Hello
I don't see a computeJacobian routine. Missing those terms is not going to help convergence.
You could try using AD? See the page about automatic differentiation in the website
If not then you should check out our page in troubleshooting failed solves. There's good advice on diagnosing convergence issues
Guillaume

I have given it a go writing it as AD, what do i need to change here to make it AD?
I want to clarify, what happens to the boundary condition on the other variable in this case. Will it also be adjusted? Will it default to a different BC?
As you now have one BC that's active on one variable, but actually it is acting on 2 variables, so will both variables be adjusted as required?

Still not working:
/home/lstein/projects/sc_res/src/BCs/SuperBC.C: In member function 'virtual ADReal SuperBC::computeQpResidual()':
/home/lstein/projects/sc_res/src/BCs/SuperBC.C:28:20: error: no match for 'operator[]' (operand types are 'const type' {aka 'const MetaPhysicL::DualNumber<double, MetaPhysicL::SemiDynamicSparseNumberArray<double, long unsigned int, MetaPhysicL::NWrapper<53> >, true>'} and 'const unsigned int')
   28 |   auto u_value = _u[_qp];
      |                    ^
make: *** [/home/lstein/projects/moose/framework/build.mk:149: /home/lstein/projects/sc_res/build/unity_src/BCs_Unity.x86_64-conda-linux-gnu.opt.lo] Error 1

```

ah ok at least this is consistent.
I think because there is only 1 value to _u on a node (there is no qp loop on a node) you do NOT need to index.
so just _u not _u[_qp]

thank you,
that has fixed the making of it.
The solve still isn't converging.
I want to clarify, what happens to the boundary condition on the other variable in this case. Will it also be adjusted? Will it default to a different BC?
As you now have one BC that's active on one variable, but actually it is acting on 2 variables, so will both variables be adjusted as required?

It wont get 'adjusted' but it should converge to a configuration that meets the equation you imposed with the nodal BC. What happens to the BC also depends a lot on how you wrote the equations in the kernels.
Can you set preset = false to the BC?
btw what variable types (finite element type) are the two variables?
This is the troubleshooting advice page btw:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/application_usage/failed_solves.html

The variable types are both first Lagrange.
It is now all working.
Thank you very much Guillamume!

Looking closer at my results, it appears now that the variables _u and Psi_Im are not able to change from the initial condition set for them on the boundary.
I had hopped that they would still change, just with the additional constraint u^2 + psi_im^2 = 1 on the boundary.
Any ideas?

What are the physics you're trying to solve here? Electromagnetics? Wave propagation?

I am modelling the behaviour of superconductors as they move from a superconducting to a normal resistive state by solving the Time-Dependent Ginzburg-Landau Equations for a dirty superconductor. https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00683522
The model is working well currently and shows the behaviour expected for boundary conditions where $|\psi|=0$. But I would like to model superconducting boundary conditions, where the magnitude of the complex order parameter $|\psi|=1$. Following your advice, I handle the real and imaginary parts of the order parameter separately, so I am looking to implement that $\psi_{Re}^2+\psi_{Im}^2=1$.
@cticenhour @aaelmeli I think you have worked on similar problems. Do you have advice on doing this?
Do you use the same BC for |psi| = 0?

Hi
You may want to implement something like CoupledVarNeumannBC that is customized to your case. I think the current implementation does not help you but it may be a good start to get to what you want. The following is an example of how I used CoupledVarNeumannBC to couple the real and imaginary variables scaled with a coefficient on some boundary. Also, consider using a direct solver for your verifications so that you make sure that the Jacobian is computed accurately.
    type = CoupledVarNeumannBC
    variable = uyi #imaginar variable
    boundary = '3'
    v = uyr #real variable
    coef = '${fparse -rho*omega*C_sr}' #some scaling factor which is a function of the shear wave speed, frequency and density"

Hi @aaelmeli,
I have had a look at the CoupledVarNeumannBC, and it looks very similar to what I have been doing.
I notice that the difference is that CoupledVarNeumannBC uses an IntegratedBC. Is this something I should try instead of the NodalBC? Does that make sense in this case?
Just to clarify, when you use CoupledVarNeumannBC are the values of both uyi and uyr changed/adjusted on the boundary in this case, or does one of these values stay fixed?

It would make sense to me if it isn't possible to write a BC in this way, as I can't imagine wanting a BC to act on, and adjust, 2 variables is standard.
Thanks for all the help so far everyone.
Writing boundary conditions for degrees of freedom that are functions of other degrees of freedom is very common, so in that sense what you are doing is "standard"

Thats reassuring.
If the issue is to do with the natural condition being applied that the flux across the boundary is zero, how would I stop enforcing that, without setting it to a value as such?
You can write a "do-nothing" boundary condition. So essentially you can write a BC that is your surface term coming from integration by parts

Do you use the same BC for |psi| = 0?

To enforce |psi|=0 I have just been using a standard Dirichlet BC, as psi_R=psi_I=0 in this case, so I presumed it would be better practice (and more computationally efficient?) to use the Dirichlet BC in that case.

We do something like this in tensor mechanics with:  https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/bcs/PenaltyInclinedNoDisplacementBC.html
where we want to enforce a zero displacement on the normal component of a surface so that it remains planar.  To do that we need to "tie" together the displacement components on that surface.  Displacement is a vector so each component is its own degree of freedom.  This enforces a dirichlet boundary condition weakly.  Maybe @jiangwen84 or @hugary1995 or @bwspenc would know if the penalty bc could enforce the bc you want.

node.title: How to solve complex PDE (i.e with imaginary part) with MOOSE?
node.bodyText:
Hi, I was wondering if this is possible and was curious how to go about it. Say I have a PDE of the form
iw*u - d^2/dx^2(u) = 0 (but in 3D)
so an expression with both complex and real parts. How could I go about solving it in MOOSE? The FEM discretization will still have a complex number attached. Would I run the real and complex parts independently?
Since I'm coupling this with an optimization problem (i.e I am trying to optimize material properties) that could be an issue. I guess I would need to optimize outside of MOOSE with a script and then re-do the simulations each time. Or what other options do I have?

Hello
There's been a few posts on that lately. I think the main idea is to create two equations that will end up being coupled

one for the real part of the equation
one for the imaginary part

We have an optimization module in moose that is integrated and can work with several equations. I dont think you ll need to use an external optimizer necessarily
Guillaume

I guess this is more of a math question than a MOOSE one but let's say the expression was:
iw*u - d^2/dx^2(u) = f(u)
Would the two PDEs be:
iw*u = Im(f(u) .......................(1)

d^2/dx^2(u) = Re(f(u)) ...................(2)

with the overall solution being
u = Re(u) + Im(u)
Did I get that right? But even still, u in both expressions can be complex valued.

no I think you need to replace u with X (Re(u)  and i Y. (Im(u))
so
w X -d2x Y = Im(f)
and
-w Y - d2x X = Re(f)
Ahh I see! That makes sense, thank you.
We do something like this here:  https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/tensor_mechanics/1d_elastic_waves.html

node.title: SinglePhaseFluidProperties error with NaKFluidProperties
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am trying to use THM to predict the outlet conditions of a sodium-potassium cooled thermal microreactor. I am following directly from the single phase flow THM tutorial, and have used the conjugate heat transfer example as a template to begin with. I've effectively adjusted TH properties for what I'm modeling, including the fluid. I use NaKFluidProperties to define the fluid and get the following error when running on lemhi:
The following error occurred in the object "nak", of type "NaKFluidProperties".

nak: virtual void SinglePhaseFluidProperties::p_from_v_e(libMesh::Real, libMesh::Real, libMesh::Real&, libMesh::Real&, libMesh::Real&) const derivatives not implemented.

I'm confused on whether this error is telling me that the variable p_from_v_e isn't implemented in my own input file or if that has not been implemented in general? In going through NaKFluidProperties documentation I didn't find that variable to input so I'm confused what the solution moving forward is. Thanks in advance!

Hello
This is not an input file problem, it s a missing implementation in the source code for the fluid property.
If you look at the NaKFluidProperties.h header file, you ll see that this routine does not exist.
To move forward you will need to implement it. This can be challenging for these weakyl/incompressible fluids as (v, e) variables are both only correlated to temperature and not pressure.
Guillaume
Okay that makes sense, thanks so much for the response!
Btw if you get them implemented and they work fine we would be glad to see these routines contributed to the module.

node.title: SidesetInfoVectorPostprocessor with use_displaced_mesh=true
node.bodyText:
Hi moose community,
I'm trying to get the bounding box of a sideset and found the "SidesetInfoVectorPostprocessor" which reports this as metadata.
For the undeformed configuration is works, but when I set "use_displaced_mesh=true", than the debug version gives
Assertion `_boundary_data.find(_current_boundary_id) != _boundary_data.end()' failed
_current_boundary_id not found in _boundary_data.
at .../moose/framework/src/vectorpostprocessors/SidesetInfoVectorPostprocessor.C, line 82

and the opt version results in a core dump.
This file reproduces the issue:
sideset_info.i.zip
Should this actually work or are there different ways to get a bounding box?
Thanks
Maik

Hello
The easiest way to get a bounding box for a sideset is to run the simulation with --mesh-only on the command line or with show_info = true in a mesh generator.
Of course neither of these work with displaced meshes, unless you reload the mesh in a FileMeshGenerator after having it displaced
I ll take a look at the file
Guillaume

Thank you for reporting the issue. I put up a patch here
#26780
Thanks you for the quick response and solution!

node.title: Updating MOOSE
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I have MOOSE installed on two machines: Mac (M1 chip) and a Linux machine (VM) and am having issues updating both. Before updating they worked fine and I'm unsure how to resolve these issues. Any help is appreciated, thanks!
Issue with Mac version: I fail 4 tests when testing the install of MOOSE and am unsure how to resolve these.

Issue with Linux version: When I try to update conda I get this error. How do I fix this? I tried to revert to an older version, but no matter the version I specify it gives me the same error. I've tried looking in the channels for an active version but could not find anything.

Hello
On the mac:
These are VTK and IGA (which we support only with a newer version of exodus). They are both rather uncommon so I would move on even with these errors. If you run the diagnostics script in moose/scripts I will create an issue and we can address it later.
For linux:
I think this is an old channel.
You need to delete the idaholab channels with conda config --remove  + the idaholab channels
then add the new one
conda config --add channels https://conda.software.inl.gov/public

Guillaume

Thanks! I was able to resolve the Mac version.
For the Linux version though I'm now getting an error when pulling the most recent version of MOOSE. I have no work done in the heat conduction module. My version of MOOSE hasn't been updated since early-mid 2021 if that is helpful information.

The heat conduction module was renamed to heat transfer.
You can try moving that folder into the heat transfer module, git adding that then continuing the rebase
That works, thank you so much!

node.title: Error when compilling
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I have to install a specific version of moose (tag 2023-06-13), so I follow the installation steps in moose website and  made some changes:

conda activate moose
mkdir -p ~/projects
cd ~/projects
git clone -b 2023-06-13 https://github.com/idaholab/moose.git

when I build moose:
cd ~/projects/moose/test
make -j 6

It failed and shows:

Hello
The errors point to mismatched versions between moose and the wasp and libmesh packages.
From the mamba list you do have packages for these two that are older and should match.
There should be a file in the moose folder that keeps track of the version of these packages that you should have. I can't recall the name right now but you should be able to find it with grep
Guillaume

Here is the info of wasp and libmesh by running versioner.py :
install: moose-wasp=2023.05.01=build_0
install: moose-libmesh=2023.04.19=build_1

I am not sure they're a match for the specific version of moose (tag 2023-06-13).
Acturally, I have tried installed a later version of gcc (gcc 13.1.0.), and the error is gone.

Running moose/scripts/versioner.py is indeed the sure tell way of identifying the versions of moose-$$$$$ packages you need to install.
Because you are after an install built ~half a year ago, there is no trackable moose-dev Conda package (we were not doing that up until more recently). Instead, you will want to install those two package versions you listed. Those are indeed the right versions, and is not a mistake.
Because Conda is good at solving dependencies, you can do:
conda install moose-libmesh=2023.04.19=build_1 moose-dev
and it will grab the compatible moose-dev built for this version of moose-libmesh, and thus everything else this version of moose-dev would install, all at the correct dates/builds:
    moose-dev-2023.06.07       |          build_0           3 KB  https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
    moose-libmesh-2023.04.19   |          build_1        35.7 MB  https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
    moose-libmesh-vtk-9.2.6    |       hb552863_1        29.7 MB  https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
    moose-mpich-4.0.2          |          build_8           7 KB  https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
    moose-petsc-3.16.6         |          build_8        23.6 MB  https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
    moose-test-tools-2023.08.31|  py310h39238f2_0           4 KB  https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
    moose-tools-2023.05.12     |  py310h39238f2_0           4 KB  https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
    moose-wasp-2023.05.01      |          build_0         639 KB  https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
@milljm Thanks for your reply. It's helpful!
Additionally, I'd like to inquire about the paths (bin) of gcc and mpich   after installing moose using conda and activating the moose environment

Activation scripts in Conda are found in:
conda activate moose
cd $CONDA_PREFIX/etc/conda/activate.d/
Specifically the moose-mpich package is located here:
conda activate moose
cat $CONDA_PREFIX/etc/conda/activate.d/activate_moose-mpich.sh
We set CC, CXX, etc, which point to Conda's MPICH MPI wrapper. The wrapper will then point to the compiler. You can ask the MPI wrapper about what compiler it will 'wrap' to by supplying the -show argument:
mpicc -show
x86_64-conda-linux-gnu-cc ...
As you will see, it is not simply gcc. It will be a special name set by the Conda-Forge developers. I suspect they did this to prevent accidental usage of the system compiler gcc.
which x86_64-conda-linux-gnu-cc
~/miniforge3/envs/moose/bin/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu-cc
Thank you for your detailed reply!

node.title: std::cout on MOOSE
node.bodyText:
All,
I am using a PenaltyInterfaceDiffusion type of an object at an interface. I am trying to see the fluctuations of value using “std::cout << “ time = “ << _t << “ u_value = “ << u_value << std::endl;”
where “u_value “ is the variable name of interest here.
Then, I get like:
time = 100 u_value = (-3.62547e-06,{})
.
.
time = 100 u_value = (0.454298,{(7494,3.90874e-11), (7497,1160.03), (7704,1.45876e-10), (7707,4329.28), (16830,0), (16831,-2.50755e-05), (16836,0), (16837,-9.35832e-05)})
.
.
“time = 100 u_value = (-3.62547e-06,{})” seems that u_value = -3.62547e-06 at time = 100.
What about
time = 100 u_value = (0.454298,{(7494,3.90874e-11), (7497,1160.03), (7704,1.45876e-10), (7707,4329.28), (16830,0), (16831,-2.50755e-05), (16836,0), (16837,-9.35832e-05)})?
Are 7494, 7497, 7704, 7707, 16830, 16831, 16836, 16837 the quadrature point index?
My model is 2D and why 8 points?
What are the values to the right of these?
Please help.
S. Thomas

Hello
No these are the automatic differentiation indices. They are actually the derivatives of the value with regards to rhe degrees of freedom, and the indices (the big integers because they are global indices) of these dofs
Guillaume

Thank you very much, Guillaume , as always.
So, u_value = -3.62547e-06 for the first one, and u_value = 0.454298  for the second one are the values I have, aren't they?
Please confirm.
S. Thomas
exactly
